001package imagingbook.lib.tuples;
002
003/**
004 * Elementary implementation of tuples, i.e, ordered sequences
005 * of items of arbitrary types.
006 * Tuples are generally immutable and their main use is to get methods
007 * return multiple values with maximum compile-time safety.
008 * A concrete tuple class is defined for
009 * each "arity", e.g., {@link Tuple2} for 2 elements.
010 * Currently tuple classes for 2, 3 and 4 elements are defined.
011 * <br>
012 * A tuple may be instantiated using either the class constructor, e.g.,
013 * <pre>new Tuple2&lt;Integer, String&gt;(10, "Foo")</pre>
014 * or the associated static method 
015 * <pre>Tuple2.of(10, "Foo")</pre>
016 * Individual tuple elements can be accessed (read-only) by the associated
017 * field names, e.g. {@code f0}, {@code f1} ... etc.
018 * There are no getter methods.
019 * @author WB
020 *
021 */
022public interface Tuple {
023        
024        
025        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
026        
027        public static void main(String[] args) {
028                Tuple2<Integer, String> tA = new Tuple2<>(10, "Foo");
029                Tuple tB = new Tuple2<Integer, String>(-3, "Bar");
030                Tuple tC = Tuple2.from(17, "Kaputnik");
031                System.out.println("tA = " + tA.toString());
032                System.out.println("tB = " + tB.toString());
033                System.out.println("tC = " + tC.toString());
034                
035                int k = tA.get0();
036                String s = tA.get1();
037                
038                System.out.println("tA.f0 = " + tA.get0().toString());
039                System.out.println("tA.f1 = " + tA.get1().toString());
040                
041                System.out.println("tA class = " + tA.getClass());
042                System.out.println("tB class = " + tB.getClass());
043                System.out.println("tC class = " + tC.getClass());
044        }
045}
046
047
